timeline.message:
Replace EagerSession.NativeReference with JavaCPP Pointer

Also upgrade JavaCPP to 1.5.3 and TensorFlow to 2.2.0-rc3

timeline.bodyText: Can we avoid side effect assignment here? I'd much prefer two lines, one for the assignment and one for the session.attach call.
timeline.author: Craigacp

timeline.bodyText:
That's a new op that needs to be reclassified to the right package. In fact, it should replace the actual QuantizedConcat op that is found under org.tensorflow.op.quantization.
Here's how to do it:

Duplicate the file api_def_QuantizedConcat.pbtxt to api_def_QuantizedConcatV2.pbtxt in the same folder.
Replace the endpoint in the old file by visibility: SKIP, like in this one
Replace the graph_op_name in the new file by QuantizedConcatV2
timeline.author: karllessard

replies.bodyText: Could you push that to my branch? Or I'll just leave those changes out and you can do it before or after we merge this PR?
replies.author: saudet

replies.bodyText: Yeah I can do that
replies.author: karllessard

timeline.bodyText:
If I recall correctly what @EronWright was envisioning for the reference counts is that it could be possible for the session to "grab" the ownership of the opHandle when it gets attached to it, instead of explicitly releasing it like in few places in this PR.
I guess it is done like this because in JavaCPP, you need to explicitly retain a reference so its count is 1, instead of having an initial value of 1. Would you mind explaining again why it needs to be like this?
timeline.author: karllessard

replies.bodyText:
When we're inside a scope (as in PointerScope), the count does get initialized to 1 by default. But when we're outside of any scope, it stays to 0, as a flag to indicate that reference counting is disabled. We need to enable it manually. If a Pointer would own itself automatically, then the count would start at 2 when initialized inside a scope, and so users would need to release them manually, even inside of a scope. It would make the use of scope pointless.
The idea is to do everything with PointerScope, then we don't need to call anything else, and everything is done behind the scenes, since the scopes own all the Pointer objects. It works exactly like RAII in C++. If you would like to understand better the motivation behind this, please read up on C++ and RAII!
replies.author: saudet

replies.bodyText: Then why not working to integrate a bit better the PointerScope in this PR? How would that work, the EagerSession needs to extend from it?
replies.author: karllessard

replies.bodyText: No, we just need to change a few things to be able to pass scopes around a bit more. Sure, let's do it now while we're at it.
replies.author: saudet

replies.bodyText: Ok, it's done!
replies.author: saudet

timeline.bodyText: In EagerOperation constructor, we attach the opHandle to the session, which was already attached to it in the constructor of this class, before we detach it here. So if I understand correctly, attaching more than once the same resource to an EagerSession (therefore to a PointerScope) requires to detach it the same amount of time?
timeline.author: karllessard

replies.bodyText: Yes, that's how reference counting works.
replies.author: saudet

replies.bodyText: Is this a problem?
replies.author: saudet

timeline.bodyText:
What do we need both nativeRefs and nativeResources? If I understand correctly, nativeRefs are detached resources that are cleared only on safe points?
The purpose of safe points was mainly to allow releasing resources while a session is active but without having a separate thread for garbage-collection. Is the GC thread in JavaCPP is always running? If it cannot be disabled, then we don't need to support safe-points. If it can be disabled, can we link this option with the picked-up strategy then?
timeline.author: karllessard

replies.bodyText:
We can remove those options. I would vote for this. I wasn't sure myself what was their purpose...
JavaCPP starts a thread for GC by default, yes, but it should be considered more or less like a safety net. It can be disabled with a system property, but it's pretty much for debug purposes only:
http://bytedeco.org/javacpp/apidocs/org/bytedeco/javacpp/Pointer.html#referenceQueue
I haven't encountered a user who wanted to have it disabled as a "feature", yet anyway.
replies.author: saudet

replies.bodyText: Why do the queues in JavaCPP call System.gc()? It's not guaranteed that that method does anything, and what it does is probably GC algorithm dependent. Does this work across all the GCs in Hotspot?
replies.author: Craigacp

replies.bodyText: Like I said, it's a safety net, precisely because Java does not provide any guarantees that anything gets done at all, it shouldn't be relied upon.
replies.author: saudet

replies.bodyText: Then for the sake of simplicity, I opt to remove these options as well, the timing is still good for doing such changes. Anyway we can't disable the GC thread only at the eager session level anymore so they don't make much sense to have them there, if they have to be restored, it would be in a different place.
replies.author: karllessard

replies.bodyText: "Safety net" isn't the right analogy. System.gc() is actually a last-ditch effort, but it usually helps avoid OutOfMemoryError, so that's why it's there.
replies.author: saudet

timeline.message: Skip MKL-specific op and update protos (#1)

timeline.bodyText:
Can you please elaborate more on how PointerScope is working?
For instance, the scope define in this method is not passed anywhere so I assume that the pointer created by TFE_Op.newOp is automatically attached to it on creation? Then, since we are already in the scope of another PointerScope (the one passed as outputScope), would it be automatically attached to it as well if we were not declaring a new one here (and shouldn't that be enough)?
If it is not required, I think it would make the code easier to follow not having so many scopes declared during the process.
timeline.author: karllessard

replies.author: karllessard

replies.bodyText:
Can you please elaborate more on how PointerScope is working?


http://bytedeco.org/news/2018/07/17/bytedeco-as-distribution/
karllessard/tensorflow-java-sandbox#3


For instance, the scope define in this method is not passed anywhere so I assume that the pointer created by TFE_Op.newOp is automatically attached to it on creation? Then, since we are already in the scope of another PointerScope (the one passed as outputScope), would it be automatically attached to it as well if we were not declaring a new one here (and shouldn't that be enough)?

Yes, that's the general idea. We need the new scopes to clean up any local resources that we don't want lying around.

If it is not required, I think it would make the code easier to follow not having so many scopes declared during the process.

Surely, but I don't see an easier way of doing this, short of doing reference counting manually. Would you like to go that way? :) FWIW, to make it prettier, this pattern should really be integrated into the Java language. There's still most likely some more that can be done at the library level. I'll be updating JavaCPP with any ideas that help, for sure, but I'm not having any more for now...
replies.author: saudet

replies.bodyText:
can't we simply do this?

Yes, but this is not what we have. We've got at least the status object to deallocate here.
replies.author: saudet

replies.bodyText: I'm refactoring this a bit to get rid of those temporary scopes by using the scopes already available in the session objects. I'll push the changes soon.
replies.author: saudet

replies.bodyText:
But the status will be deallocated ultimately by the outer scope as well, right?
I suggest then that we opt for simplicity and that we let the outer scopes release resources allocated by their private helper methods, which will probably end up being inlined anyway if we can them simple enough.
I understand it might be less « safe » but I would be very surprised if something goes wrong and I take full responsibility if it does :)
replies.author: karllessard

replies.bodyText: Sure, we can refactor some more and start inlining those private methods. We don't need to keep them separate now that we're not writing JNI anymore. Anyway, let me know if it's good enough with the latest changes.
replies.author: saudet

replies.bodyText: Yep, looks good!
replies.author: karllessard

timeline.message: Get rid of temporary output PointerScope objects
